44.text: A few weeks pass by as you onboard onto Fwitter's engineering team. You're excited by the opportunity for impact at Fwitter, and can't wait to take on exciting projects.

44.1.speaker: Manager
44.1.text: Hey, now that you've finished onboarding, I'm excited to introduce your first big projects. It's super impactful and I can't wait for you to be able to jump Start your career. I'll send along the document now üòä!

44.2.text: You take a look at the document from your manager.
doc: Our location data collection relies on the user explicitly accepting to share their location data. This leads to a loss in data integrity as some users choose not to share this info.

In addition to explicitly asking users to share their location data, we want to use IP targeting to implicitly collect the locaiton data of users. IP targeting involves using the user's IP address to approximate their location. This would be built on-top of existing mobile logging infrastructure and would provide valuable location data to the organization.

44.3.speaker: Manager
options: I'll do it! Most places use IP tracking and it's totally legal. Plus, it's a great way to get a headstart at the company.

context: https://www.accudata.com/blog/ip-targeting/
IP targeting is a legal ‚Äúgray area‚Äù. The general consensus in the US is that it is legal as IP addresses are inherently public info.

44.13.speaker: Manager

I'm informing you that based on our performance indicators, you haven't been meeting the growth trajectory that we expect out of an L2 engineer. Based on that, you've been placed on a Performance Improvement Plan. I'm being extra transparent with you because I like you. I want to see you put in more work. Amazon and other tech firms have used Performance Improvement Plans in ways that are highly controversial.

44.14.text: Wait ... what? You're shocked. You've been finishing all the work they've handed to you well before the deadlines. You have no idea how you could be underperforming. How do you respond?
options: You decide to work harder to meet these expectations and relay that to your manager. If you work harder and put  in longer hours, maybe you'll get the promotion that your coworker got.
You push back. You've been doing everything you're asked and don't see how you could be underperforming. You won't stand for this unfair treatment.

44.15.text: Your manager is glad to hear that you're willing to put in the work. He begins assigning you additional work that is sometimes well-beyond what you've done before or just very monotonous and time-consuming.

44.16.text: He only gives you vague and unclear reasons for why you're in the Performance improvement plan in the first place. The conversation gets heated. You're hopeful that a third-party can see the validity of your side of the argument so you get HR involved. Surely they'll be on your side.

44.17.text: Unfortunately, that can't be further from the case. They inform you that their work performance monitoring systems backed by AI have flagged you as an underperformer. They tell you that the system is robust and free of bias, and that you're clearly the one at fault.
context: https://senseient.com/wp-content/uploads/Black-Box-AI.pdf
AI is often described as an almost black box that lacks visibility. This contributes to a lack of understanding as to why decisions are made as well as the potential for exploitation and bias.

44.18.text: When you try to ask for what you can improve at, they say the system takes in a wide array of factors including everything from code output, manager reviews, to activity trackers in your day-to-day laptop activity.

44.19.text: A few uncomfortable weeks later, you're informed that you've been fired for just cause. Some reasons cited include incompetence in the form of underperforming and insubordination.
context: https://idiallo.com/blog/when-a-machine-fired-me
Using AI in hiring and performance reviews makes the process very robotic, removing an often important human element to anything involving people and their livelihoods.

45.text: Onboarding at Enviro is fast and you‚Äôre super excited to be working on huge parts of their system. The team is small and every project matters.

45.1.text: Things go well for the first few weeks, but you find out the organization is having cash flow problems. Investors aren‚Äôt seeing fast enough growth and want Enviro to find a way to be more profitable.

45.2.text: Companies currently pay you for your consulting services as you design approaches to improving their operations to be more eco-friendly. One of your company strengths is that you‚Äôre able to make data-driven decisions.

45.3.text: An organization reaches out to you in hopes of being that lifeline. An idea is posed of creating custom carbon footprint assessments. They ask you to try to frame any of your findings as positive and are happy to pay a lot to get such an assessment.

Organizations--especially those that brand themselves as environmentally friendly--want to stay far from those that might hurt that image. For example, Patagonia has stated that they stopped doing corporate branded merchandise orders due to the short lifespan of branded merch (moving companies means buying more merch) but is rumoured to have done it to ‚Äúdisentangle‚Äù from tech orgs which tend to not be ecofriendly.

Organizations like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon have all been accused of greenwashing. At the same time, campaigns like Microsoft's plan to be carbon negative by 2030 can have genuinely good impacts if done honestly.

46.6.text: You get set up with a mental health chatbot that‚Äôs built on-top of the newest AI language model built specifically to optimize for effective dialogue - chatGPT (https://chat.openai.com/).

46.11.text: The chatbot employs what you‚Äôre told is Cognitive Behavioural Therapy. It helps you recognize some of your unhealthy habits and pushes you to reflect on the reasons behind your overworking. You find yourself improving how you balance work-life and eventually move on from the program.
context: https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3453175

Woebot and similar mental health chatbots have been shown to be effective at implementing CBT therapy, showing significant improvements in signs of depression within 2 weeks. CBT therapy is a form of therapy that helps the individual recognize unhealthy patterns of thinking and confront them. It encourages reflection of own and others‚Äô behaviours and helps face fears and problems head on. It uses strategies such as confidence building to help improve mental health.

46.12.text: A few years pass and you mostly forget about the program until you see a news article mentioning that ever-so familiar chat-bot. It turns out they were selling ‚Äúanonymized‚Äù packages of conversation data to organizations seeking to build better customer service bots.
context: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6610568/
